sample.db:para: The glaze dried very quickly. Thick layer. As can be seen, a gold/lighter brown goes through, when thickness increases.
Convenient thickness for brushing. Note the brown spots. Miss coloring, oven accident?
Very thick. Very hard to stir, could it be the temperature?
W11 had an extra layer on the second level.
Dipped, three seconds.
Dipped, three seconds.
Frosted Jade across whole, with Green Hue on top at the right corner, diagonal.
2 seconds dipping.
4 seconds dipping.
2 seconds dipping.
4 seconds dipping.
2 seconds dipping.
4 seconds dipping.
Even though the glaze is very thick, it looks sane. Only bad indication of thickness can be seen on W7 where a tiny empty spot can be seen. Maybe it could have been avoided by polishing.
It's dipped three times but it doesn't really show. That's good, since it means dipping time is less of a factor.
Despite being very thick, it is very elegant. Doesn't move at all, when judging from other pieces.

No glaze, used pens. Top, top left, and left side is with a ballpoint pen, while the bottom right is with a black lead pencil. As the brick shows there's no trace, except for the mechanical marks that the ball pen did.
Drew with black lead graphite pencil, and then glazed on top of that. As the brick shows there's not a single trace, so using pen is ok.
Too thin.
White black diagonally across the brick. Both glazes to thin, or at least to quick dipping.
Kinda ok, but it's a pity that the yellow is cold, even though Saint Thomas has a tad of iron.
Dropped it in the floor on 2007-11-17, glued it with cyanoacrylate glue.

Visible white spots on the sample. As if the transparent hadn't dissolved. Looks cool, annoying small spots, caused by gas extrusion? The clear metal feel to it might be avoided with less oxide, maybe.
This is traditional dark chocolate, both in texture and color. Doubt more stain will turn this black.
Maybe mixed up with T42.
Maybe mixed up with T35. The backside reads 92.
Green Hue is on top, at the bottom. So Frosted Jade was applied first, in other words. Frosted Jade was dried a bit first, but not completely, since the bisque was a tad cold.
The opposite of T39. Frosted Jade is on top, at the bottom. So Green Hue was applied first, in other words. Green Hue was thoroughly dried with hot air gun.
Green Hue were on 45, Frosted Jade on 44.
Convenient thickness. Brushed three different thickness.
Brushed three different thickness.

Applied is a slip consisting only of dilluted clay, namely, PRNF 4005 from Cerama Collet S.a, WBB Fuchs GmbH & Co. Applied the slip directly after having cut out the sample, didn't wait. The glazed part is brown, tilitng towards (khaki) green.

Applied is a porcelain slip. Except for the last layer, the slip was applied directly after having cut out the sample, didn't wait. The transparent glaze turned out really well, think I dipped it for a long time.
Easy to brush with. The last layer was thoroughly dried before applying. 56 is scratched on the back.
Four layers.
Four layers. Extremely thick, like semi-dry tooth paste.
Five layers.

The first layer has three vertical stripes which from left to right are white, black and green. The second layer has three horizontal stripes which from top to bottom are white, black, and green. All was done with tape masking, and each stripe had two even coats. This gives a range of a combinations. For instance, in the top right corner one finds white on top of green, and in the left bottom corner green on top of white.

The black leaked into the white in the first layer and white leaked onto black at the top on the second layer. There was another leakage, not noted down, as well. Basically, the tape for flexible curves couldn't hold it out.
Four layers. The number in the top right corner is drawn over with black AXNER underglaze, and the back says 100. Oops.
Four layers.
Four layers.
Five layers, I think. This brush-on acts quite thin.

The left corner has Lichen Green brushed on top in one thorough layer. In the middle there was a drop of water which gave a visible texture, maybe it shows up after firing. On the right was sprayed, which flooded in a bit under the tape, a fixativ. It prevents the surface from being powderish, but doesn't repell water, athough slows down suction a bit. Not that that is of any use. However, it makes handling a glazed piece with ones hands less destructive. Assuming it doesn't have an effect on after glaze burn. The fixativ was Winsor & Newton Artists' Fixativ, transparent, non removable.
The frosted jade was one long even dip.
2007-12-21 So the Lichen Green area turned into as graphite, and no sign at all from the fixativ. Top right corner is cool, the one below a bit too.

First, three layers of orange was applied with the usual stair case approach. That is, at the top one layer, and at the bottom three layers. On top of that was three layers of yellow coated over the whole. That is, at the top one finds one layer of orange and and three layers of yellow, and at the bottom three layers of orange and three layers of yellow.

First, three layers of red was applied with the usual stair case approach. That is, at the top one layer, and at the bottom three layers. On top of that was three layers of yellow coated over the whole. That is, at the top one finds one layer of red and and three layers of yellow, and at the bottom three layers of red and three layers of yellow.
2007-12-21 Hilarious. Blue and green. I have to have mixed something up.
Four layers
Three layers of black.
Four layers.
Four layers. It was hard to get a thick layer of transparent glaze on top even though the piece was a bit warm. The black prevented suction.

At the bottom, vertically, from left to right: white, black and green. On top, horizontally, from top to bottom: white, black and green. Each strip had two layers, so in total there's four layers on each square.
Five solid layers. Should be fired standing vertically, for testing viscosity.
2008-01-03 Loaded it standing more than vertically: maybe 15 degrees "forward."
Obviously the bottle have been incorrectly labeled. This is not the red spot iron glaze, this is a glossy dark blue. Whatever it is, it didn't run.

Slight pink shade(before fired at least) due to the Flint. Very large particles, very powderish. Saturated it with fixativ for that reason. Don't think the third layer is any thicker, due to that it solved away the underlying layers, because of them being too moist. From a 200g test batch.
Looks like porridge. Hilarious, the glaze is for Cone 10, about 1300 C, so the glaze probably didn't melt.

Hence, the only difference to is that this one was sieved. Used mixer first, and the substance ran through the sieve as water. Beyond the mixing, another reason to it being vastly different could be that it had been mixed in water for a couple of days, and hence dissolved better.
Leach base with zirconium oxide added.
Leach base with zirconium oxide added but twice as much as T105. Think it has a small contamination of Candace Black.
The shrinking is not caused by the Cobolt oxide, since it's also present in .
Wrote with oxide pen, HC Hobbyceram Sottosmalto NERO 606.

Used mixer for a long time, from a 200 g batch. After the second step, heated with hot air gun. It is so powderish that one layer flaked off. Needs bentonite/CMC for production. Seems the cobolt dispersed unevenly, small black spots at the tops. Sealed of with fixativ. 100ml weighted 178g.
Used mixer for a long time, from a 200 g batch. Despite only having a gravity of 40, it was extremely thick. The hydrometer moved slowly and the layers were perceived as very thick.

2008-02-23 It's sort of obvious why this turned out as it did. Zinc oxide is a flux, since it's absent the thing didn't melt, and since Tin Oxide is an opacifier, it isn't transparent. I wonder what caused the graphite-look which can be seen on the second and third layer, and a little bit on the first.
The middle layer had a lot less Cobber on its surface, for some reason. Hm, that's because the cobber settles quickly, quicker than the others. Bentonite needed.
Right after mixing, so lots of air bubbles. From 200 g batch.
Right after mixing, so lots of air bubbles. From 200 g batch.
